commander.name: Charles Walter Allfrey
commander.previous_service: Promoted to acting lieutenant-general March 1942. Led V Corps through Operation Torch landings November 1942. Commanded forces in Tebourba sector including mixed British and US formations. Known for defensive operations against Axis counterattacks.

command.headquarters_location: Tebourba-Medjez el Bab sector, Northern Tunisia

M4 Sherman.note: 6th Armoured Division regiments (26th Armoured Brigade). New equipment arriving Q1 1943.

M3 Grant/Lee.note: 6th Armoured Division, being replaced by Shermans during Q1 1943

Crusader III.note: 6th Armoured Division cruiser tank squadrons, older British design

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Mk II.note: Divisional artillery from 6th Armoured (48 guns, 2 field regiments) and 78th Infantry (72 guns, 3 field regiments). Standard British field gun.

Ordnance QF 5.5-inch Gun-Howitzer.note: Corps medium artillery regiment. Long-range counter-battery and interdiction fires.

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).note: Divisional anti-tank regiments (6th Armoured: 12, 78th Infantry: 48). Primary British AT gun 1943.

Ordnance QF 17-pounder.note: New high-velocity AT gun beginning to arrive Q1 1943. Limited numbers, corps anti-tank reserve.

Bofors 40mm.note: Corps light anti-aircraft battery (divisional AA assets separate)

Oerlikon 20mm.note: Supplementary AA defense for corps HQ

supply_logistics.supply_status: Challenging - extended supply lines from Algiers through mountainous terrain. Q1 1943 saw heavy winter rains turning roads to mud, severely hampering logistics. V Corps operating in difficult Tebourba-Medjez sector with limited trafficable routes. Supply priority shared with First Army's push toward Tunis. Fuel and ammunition adequate for defensive operations and limited offensives. Extensive motor transport required due to lack of railhead access. Water supplies adequate but required constant hauling. American Lend-Lease equipment (Shermans, Stuarts, trucks) increasing corps capability during Q1 1943.

temperature_range_c.note: Tunisian winter. Cold nights, moderate days. Heavy rains January-February turned terrain to mud. March saw improvement with spring weather arriving.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia hill country and valleys. Tebourba-Medjez el Bab sector features: steep hills (djebels) with narrow valleys, limited road network, easily defended terrain favoring defenders. Extensive olive groves and agricultural areas. Rivers and wadis prone to flooding during winter rains. Terrain channelizes movement, limiting armor employment. Mud severely restricted off-road movement during Q1 1943.
weather_environment.seasonal_impact: Heavy winter rains (January-February 1943) created severe mud conditions, bogging down vehicles and limiting offensive operations. Ground attacks often delayed due to impassable roads. March brought drying conditions and improved trafficability. Cold wet weather affected troop morale and health (respiratory illnesses common). Poor visibility during rainy periods hampered air support coordination.
environmental_challenges: Mud - roads and tracks impassable during heavy rains, limiting mobility
Limited road network - few all-weather roads, easy for enemy to block key routes
Mountainous terrain - restricts armor employment, favors infantry and artillery
River crossings - wadis flooded during rains, bridges critical chokepoints
Supply difficulties - extended lines from Algiers through mountains
Cold wet weather - health issues (trench foot, respiratory infections)
Limited observation - hilly terrain creates dead zones for artillery observers

subordinate_units.note: Under V Corps command from Operation Torch (November 1942) through mid-March 1943. Transferred to IX Corps on 12 March 1943. First major action Bou Arada (18-25 January 1943). Equipped with mix of Sherman, Grant, and Crusader tanks.

Core V Corps formation throughout Tunisia campaign. Veteran division from Operation Torch. Prominent role in northern sector operations. In February 1943, exchanged 1st (Guards) Brigade for 38th (Irish) Brigade from 6th Armoured Division.
Attached to V Corps during Q1 1943 for operations in Tebourba sector. Light infantry with limited heavy equipment. Conducted aggressive patrolling and limited offensive actions.

subordinate_units.unit_designation: Combat Command B, US 1st Armored Division
subordinate_units.note: Temporarily attached to V Corps during Q1 1943 operations. American armored combat command operating under British corps command. Demonstrated Allied cooperation during Tunisia campaign.
Attached for special operations in V Corps sector. Conducted raids, reconnaissance, and limited offensive actions. Light infantry with specialized training.
5.5-inch gun-howitzers. Counter-battery missions and long-range interdiction fires. Critical for corps operations in mountainous terrain.

Corps-level engineers (bridging, mine clearance, road maintenance in difficult terrain), signals (communications network), RASC (logistics convoys), RAOC (ordnance depots), RAMC (medical facilities, field hospitals), provost (military police, traffic control).

tactical_doctrine.role: V Corps was First Army's primary offensive formation in northern Tunisia during Q1 1943. Mission: advance eastward from Medjez el Bab toward Tunis through difficult hill country. Operations focused on seizing key terrain (djebels) dominating valleys and roads. Limited by terrain, weather, and logistics during Q1 1943 - offensive operations constrained to February's Operation Ochsenkopf (German counterattack, defended successfully) and March preparations for spring offensive. Corps held defensive positions during worst winter weather (January-February), then prepared for April offensive operations.
special_capabilities: Mixed arms coordination - infantry and armour working together in restricted terrain
Defensive expertise - held against German Operation Ochsenkopf counterattack
All-arms cooperation - British divisions, US CCB, Commandos, Paratroops
Mountain warfare adaptation - infantry-artillery coordination in hills
Experienced leadership - Allfrey, Evelegh, Keightley veteran commanders
tactical_innovations: Integration of US armored units under British corps command (Allied cooperation)
Combined arms in restrictive terrain - tanks, infantry, artillery coordination
Commando and parachute forces for aggressive patrolling and raids
Artillery dominance - massed fires compensating for limited armor mobility
Defensive depth - using terrain to channel and defeat German counterattacks
known_issues: 6th Armoured Division green and inexperienced (first combat January 1943)
Terrain severely restricted armor employment - tanks road-bound
Extended supply lines from Algiers through mountains - logistics strain
Winter weather and mud immobilized operations January-February 1943
Limited all-weather roads - movement and supply constrained
German forces held strong defensive positions on key hills (djebels)
Air support coordination difficult due to weather and terrain
tactical_doctrine.terrain_adaptations: V Corps adapted British doctrine for Tunisian hill country: infantry-led attacks to seize hills, artillery massed fires supporting infantry assaults, tanks in direct fire support rather than mobile operations (terrain too restrictive), extensive engineer support for road maintenance and bridge repair, decentralized operations (divisions operating semi-independently due to terrain compartmentalization), aggressive patrolling to maintain contact with enemy.

scenario_suitability: Tunisia Campaign Q1 1943 - northern sector operations
Operation Ochsenkopf - German counterattack (26 February - 4 March 1943)
Battle of Bou Arada - 6th Armoured Division first action (18-25 January 1943)
Corps-level command scenarios with mixed Allied forces
Winter warfare with mud and weather challenges
wargaming_data.experience_level: Mixed - 78th Division Veteran, 6th Armoured Green, Commandos Elite
special_rules: Allfrey Leadership: V Corps benefits from experienced corps commander (+1 coordination)
Terrain Restrictions: Armor movement severely limited in hill country (-2 mobility for tanks)
Mud (Q1 1943): All off-road movement reduced during January-February rains
Allied Cooperation: US CCB operates under British command (coordination challenges possible)
Artillery Advantage: British artillery massed fires doctrine (+1 to artillery effectiveness)
Green 6th Armoured: First combat operations, -1 morale until April 1943
Veteran 78th Division: +1 to combat rolls in defensive positions
historical_engagements: Race for Tunis (November-December 1942) - V Corps advance stalled by German reinforcements
Battle of Bou Arada (18-25 January 1943) - 6th Armoured Division first major action
Operation Ochsenkopf (26 February - 4 March 1943) - German counterattack defeated by V Corps
Preparations for Operation Vulcan (March 1943) - build-up for final Tunisia offensive

source: Web search: British First Army order of battle, 20 April 1943 (Wikipedia, 90% confidence) - used for April composition, extrapolated backward to Q1
Web search: Charles Allfrey biography (Wikipedia, Military Wiki, 95% confidence) - V Corps commander since March 1942
Web search: V Corps Tunisia operations Q1 1943 (multiple sources, 85% confidence) - 6th Armoured, 78th Division, attachments
Web search: 6th Armoured Division transfer to IX Corps 12 March 1943 (85% confidence) - confirms Q1 composition
Historical accounts: V Corps operations Tebourba-Medjez sector, Operation Ochsenkopf (80% confidence)
Estimated corps-level assets based on British corps organization 1943 (medium artillery, engineers, signals) (70% confidence)
known_gaps: Chief of Staff name not identified in available sources
Exact personnel counts for attached units (US CCB, Commandos, Parachute Brigade) estimated
6th Armoured Division detailed TO&E not available - tank counts estimated from standard British armoured division
Corps HQ staff breakdown estimated from typical British corps establishment 1943
Individual subordinate unit commander names below division level unknown
Exact dates of US CCB and Commando attachments not precisely documented
Equipment serial numbers and unit assignments below division level estimated
Corps medium artillery regiment establishment assumed standard 24x 5.5-inch guns

gap_documentation.6th_armoured_division_data: 6th Armoured Division file not yet extracted. Tank counts and personnel estimated from standard British armoured division establishment 1943: 242 tanks (mix Sherman, Grant, Crusader, Stuart), 14,200 personnel. Division transferred to IX Corps 12 March 1943, so only present for 2.5 months of Q1 1943.
gap_documentation.attached_units: US 1st Armored Division CCB, 1st Parachute Brigade, 1st/6th Commandos operated under V Corps command during Q1 1943 but specific strengths and equipment not detailed in sources. Estimated based on standard unit establishments.
gap_documentation.q1_1943_composition: Most detailed OOB available is 20 April 1943 (after Q1). Q1 1943 composition extrapolated backward: 6th Armoured and 78th Division known to be with V Corps January-March. By April, 1st and 4th Infantry Divisions replaced 6th Armoured (which went to IX Corps 12 March).

validation.methodology: Corps data estimated from subordinate division establishments and historical accounts. 6th Armoured Division estimated at 242 tanks and 14,200 personnel (standard British armoured division 1943). 78th Infantry Division estimated at 17,350 personnel (standard British infantry division). Attached units (US CCB, Parachute Brigade, Commandos) estimated from unit type standards. Corps-level assets (medium artillery, corps troops) estimated from British corps organization 1943. Q1 1943 specific composition based on historical accounts of V Corps operations in Tebourba-Medjez sector with 6th Armoured and 78th Division. Total personnel: 6th Armoured (14,200) + 78th Infantry (17,350) + Attachments (6,500 est.) + Corps HQ/troops (4,800 est.) = 42,850 total. Historical mission and tactical doctrine from Tunisia campaign histories and Operation Ochsenkopf accounts.

discovered_units.combat_evidence: Tunisia Campaign - Tebourba sector operations, aggressive patrolling and raiding operations. Attached to V Corps for northern Tunisia operations. Airborne infantry conducting ground operations, raiding, reconnaissance, and limited offensive actions in V Corps sector. Sources: Web search V Corps composition Tunisia Q1 1943, historical accounts of V Corps Tebourba sector operations.
discovered_units.note: British 1st Parachute Brigade attached to V Corps during Q1 1943. Not in seed file - discovered during V Corps research. Combat participation confirmed: attached for operations in northern Tunisia, conducted patrolling and raiding missions. Qualifies for inclusion as combat unit (not garrison/reserve).
